Fields.DialogueText: There you are. Did I catch you at a bad time?
Jamais! You could never.
How in the world can you stand it down here? It's noisy and grimy and hot. No offense.
None taken! I can't stand when the world slows down around me. The greater the chaos, the sharper my senses.
Even when you're sewing?
I am only fixing the clothes. Washing them can come later.

Fields.MenuText: There are cleaner places to do this.
Washing is the true test of a sewing job.
We can get new uniforms from Command, you know.

Fields.DialogueText: I know, Capitaine. I cleaned them. I, and my tireless crew!
Rather like war! A strong, well-stitched country will survive the fiercest scrubbing.
As long as we can make ours last, they are better spent elsewhere.
Et... c'est fini! What do you think?
Good as new! Is this one of the crew's?
One down. Five hundred-odd to go.
You're not seriously sewing for your whole complement.
Well, not all at once.
*ALARM*
Meet you on the bridge.
@BATTLE
Zut. Just in time, eh, Capitaine? Let's move from my beating heart to my brain!
Marseillaise, I need a report on our repair efforts from the last Morgana combat.
I am, as you can see, quite well. Repairs are completed. Are you well?
Never better.
Bonne nouvelle. Allow me to contribute. Drink this tea?
Really, I'm feeling fine.
You do not drink water only when thirsty! Come on. This pomander serves as an excellent filter.

Fields.MenuText: Marseillaise, really, I feel fine.
Smells like... perfume.
I suppose one cup can't hurt.

Fields.DialogueText: And you will stay that way once you've joined me in a cup of mint and roses.
To counter the miasma of disease. Now just imagine the taste!
Non, it can only help.
Boil some water and let's try it.
Oui! I can patch this jacket while we wait.
You'll spoil us all if you keep this up.
I will not. For every uniform I fix, I teach basic stitching to one of the crew. Some of them might teach others. Soon the whole ship will be full of expert tailors!
Who knew you could learn home economics on the front lines?
Where better?
At home? Far away from-
We cannot pick and choose the time of revolution. When it comes, we must be ready! And properly clothed.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
-Morganas?
Let's see... Hierophant reversed. Bien. I could have told myself that.
Another reading?
It's been some time since the last one, and the moment seemed auspicious.

Fields.MenuText: What made it auspicious?
Pluto wasn't talking to you?
Just a feeling?

Fields.DialogueText: It's difficult to explain an instinct. For me, when I feel I've set my affairs in order, that's when I'm most curious about whether they'll stay ordered.
Laugh if you want, Capitaine. Maybe you should try talking to it.
More or less. The art is meant to reveal more about yourself than about the mystique behind it.
So what do you see?
Well, look here, for example. Hierophant reversed. That means I should be looking within myself... challenging the world as it stands.
Sounds like you, all right.
And an obvious parallel to the eight of swords here. Indecision, conflict, old demons that need exorcising.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
They only speak the language of artillery. It would be rude not to answer thus!
That's my present and my challenges.
And what's this? The Lovers? Got a crush on someone?
Very funny, Capitaine. It could be just a very close friendship. But that's in my near future, according to this layout.
Maybe one of these Morganas wants to talk.
Capitaine, did you hear the news?
It's all anyone will talk about. Seems the politicians back home have taken an interest in you.
They want a Belle of La Marine Nationale to record a message to the troops. And they selected me!

Fields.MenuText: That doesn't surprise me. You're as French as it gets.

Fields.DialogueText: My people built me this way, Capitaine!
Flagship of the 4th Squadron, named after the national anthem... hard to think of a better candidate than you.
Ah, Capitaine, isn't it exciting?
I can't speak for the people on land. It's a long way to the battlefield from here. They might just be tired.
Ah, but I am no elected official. I am no celebrity drafted for the war effort.
That's worth something. I'm lucky to be out here with you.
Ah! I... have been thinking much the same thing, to tell you the truth.
The armies don't get encouraging words or sewing lessons from their tanks or guns. It's still war on the seas, but a friendly face helps.
*ALARM*

Fields.MenuText: Your sisters must be jealous.
Not to speak to them directly?

Fields.DialogueText: Le Triomphant has the better radio voice, I think. But don't tell her I said that.
I'm sure it's easier this way. It's hard to line up our schedule with theirs.
When the people hear me, they hear the very spirit of France herself. The homeland... and the revolution that laid its foundation!
Oui, of course. That is what I meant.
@BATTLE
Ah, Capitaine! Have you come to join in the cleanup?
It's already spotless above. Is it really necessary to spruce up down here?
If there is one casualty in every  war, it is honesty. The reasons for fighting... the toll on the populace... even the very course of the conflict.

Fields.MenuText: All five-hundred-plus?
It's not dishonest to have the place spotless?
I don't know if they'll have time for that.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I'm not asking them to memorize everyone's name.
Non, it is simple courtesy. I can be a steadfast soldier and a gracious host.
We will make time! We aren't constantly in combat. They won't be confined to quarters for their whole stay.
Solidarity, Capitaine. That is what we're aiming for. Those in the trenches need to know that we're all in this together.
Oh, very funny, Capitaine.
*ALARM*
Looks like it's time to get a little dirty.
We knew this time would come. Ça va, marins! Just like I taught you! Allons enfants de la Patrie, le jour de gloire est arrivé...
@BATTLE
Now this is a surprise.
When our government correspondents arrive, they will have the full tour of my structure. They will see the daily struggle of each sailor as they toil for a better future!
I think you might be making more of this than it's intended to be.
Let the establishment decide. They asked to speak to me. But I am more than just myself. I am my crew! I am the people!
L'état, c'est moi?
Capitaine, I promise there is a good reason for this.
Let's hear it. Why are our charts marked up with crayon?
Well, I was thinking about the guests we're about to have. As long as we're cleaning, I should welcome them with a meal as well.
And as we are out at sea... why not a delicious bouillabaisse?
That still doesn't answer my question.
I've done some research, and the areas outlined in red are where we're most likely to find the fish we need. A little rascasse rouge ought to be just the thing.

Fields.MenuText: Well, take it off. The navigation team uses these for military purposes.
We can't run the war on your shopping list.
Not monkfish?

Fields.DialogueText: I've already spoken to them, Capitaine. They thought it was funny.
Our patrol route should take us close enough to these areas that we won't have to.
If you can tell the difference, your tastes are more refined than mine.
They're going to be here any day now, Marseillaise. It's probably too late to welcome them with a bouillabaisse.
Next time? I'm talking about this time.
Will the government be satisfied with one patriotic message? Je ne pense pas. Who knows how long the war will last?
Your heart's in the right place, even if your crayons aren't.
Don't forget my ammunition!
There is always next time.
Besides, I enjoy helping out in the galley. The crew could use a taste of France from France herself.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Damn. We're getting a distress signal. And if it's coming from where I think it is...
What are we waiting for? We need to save them right away!
Right. We're headed to meet them now. If we- ACHOO!
Capitaine! How long have you been sneezing that way?

Fields.MenuText: I'm fine, Marseillaise. It's just a sneeze.
Does it really matter right now?
Not very long. Why?

Fields.DialogueText: Something is causing it, and we are getting to the bottom of what!
We did not fight all these Morganas to be laid low by some disease!
We've talked about this! I will not have anyone risking the crew.
It can't be helped. You need to get below and quarantine.
We're about to engage the enemy!
We've already engaged one, and we need to stop it from spreading! What if our correspondents catch it and bring it back to the mainland?
It's a cold, not some tropical wasting disease.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Here I am, Capitaine!
Just in time, Marseillaise. It sounds like the correspondents' armed transport is being followed by Morganas.
Grr... Fine. But at least wash your hands. And cover your face! I'll get you a scarf.
Fine. Might look rakish in battle, at least.
Ah, oui. I mean... be serious, Capitaine!
Enfin! A moment free from the press.
How are our guests finding the ship?
They are pleased, Capitaine! I think the crew have done very well in making me cozy and clean.

Fields.MenuText: Hopefully the ship doesn't burn to  the waterline without me.
I appreciate you nursing me back to health. It's nice just to catch up on paperwork.
I'm going above. They're not leaving without talking with me.

Fields.DialogueText: Not if I have anything to say about it. And I always have something to say.
And your work ethic is a true inspiration to the people. Though you would recover much more quickly if you did some slacking.
With respect, Capitaine, they are here to see me.
So they haven't recorded your message yet?
Tomorrow, Capitaine. They are assessing our patriotism... so they say.
I wasn't expecting an inspection.
It is part of why I was teaching the anthem to all of our sailors. Our guests are especially interested in the foreign crew.
Shame I can't hear it from them. ACHOO!
No arguments, Capitaine! You are not coming face to face with them until you've gone dawn to dusk without sneezing.
Interested how?
Impertinent questions about their loyalties. It is... well. It's only for a few days more.
I'd trust anyone on the crew with my life.
As would I, Capitaine. You do not have to be French to love freedom.
But the powers that be think it helps.
*ALARM*
Looks like it's go time. If only someone hadn't confined me to quarters.
We'll manage. You just drink tea and fill out the paperwork later.
@BATTLE
If it's for our armies... hmph. Well, I'll make the best of it.
Back on your feet, eh, Capitaine?
Yes, Marseillaise, I'm feeling much-
Un moment.
Marseillaise, you don't have to check for a fever. I'm fine.
If sneezing isn't enough of a symptom for you, neither is a fever.

Fields.MenuText: Aren't you afraid of getting sick?
I feel better than I have all tour. Thanks for watching over me.
Finally. I was starting to think this was a mutiny.

Fields.DialogueText: Belles aren't nearly as vulnerable as humans. Besides, the air around me is the picture of health.
It is my duty as a Belle, my duty as your Belle.
A little rebellion now and then is a good thing.
I've taken a tour of the ship. You've done a good job running things while I was down.
So when do they record your radio message?
Already done. In fact, that was the first thing they did.
How did it go?
I see that look on your face, Capitaine. You do not have to worry! I gave the men a message the whole world will think long upon.
Brr. I didn't expect your hands to be so cold.
C'est bon. I am satisfied.
The credit belongs to the crew. I've made sure to make that clear in my discussions with the correspondents.
*ALARM*
I'm looking forward to hearing it.
I always hold the people in my heart, Capitaine. You will not be disappointed.
@BATTLE
That's the last we'll see of the propagandists for now.
Such an ugly word, Capitaine.
That's what they were.
It's a new age, Capitaine. Can you imagine what the French Revolution would have accomplished if the voices of the people had been broadcast from the North Sea to the Black?

Fields.MenuText: We might not even be fighting this war.

Fields.DialogueText: No more empires... no more crowns... A certain Corsican might even have remained an artillery commander.
When do we get to hear you speak?
Within the next couple of weeks. They'll let us know when to tune in.
It's chafing at me like a burlap dress, Capitaine. The revolution will not wait!
*ALARM*
... Marseillaise, what did you say to them?
You'll see, Capitaine. I always strive to impress.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: A lot more fighting, that's for sure.
It's impossible to say. You might as well ask what Napoleon would have done with a cruiser like you.

Fields.DialogueText: One day there will be no more need for it. That is what we fight for.
Pah! That megalomaniac would have pined after me like a lovesick student.
Now we wait.
I thought you said we couldn't choose when it happens.
Non, we cannot. But should we not do all we can to prepare the way for it?
Bouillabaisse, Capitaine?
I thought you weren't done gathering fish.
I am not. But I got impatient. I thought we'd make do with what we have.
So what do you think?

Fields.MenuText: No bouillabaisse is ever wasted.
This needs... lots of salt.
Mmm. Delicious. You don't give yourself enough credit.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps not, Capitaine. But it makes the perfect one loom all the larger in my mind.
I was afraid of that. Unfortunately, I've earmarked all of it for preserving the rascasse rouge. Should we ever get our hands on some.
I appreciate it, Capitaine. But my cooking must be as tireless as my revolution.
Don't worry, Marseillaise. It's not the end of the world just because dinner didn't turn out perfectly.
Even so, Capitaine, I wanted it to be special for you. For us.
You took the time to make it. It's already special.
I am... starting to regret my eagerness.
M-merci, Capitaine! I mean... ahem. Well, the search continues!
How are you conducting it in the first place?
I found some netting and pressed some crew into service.
... Pressed some crew into service?
A little joke between me and them, Capitaine. I would never deprive anyone of their liberty.
*ALARM*
We'd better-
Don't. You're sitting right there and finishing your bouillabaisse. Wolf it down if you have to.
What about my liberty to command the crew in battle?
You make a fine point. This is not a dish worth one's rights.
@BATTLE
Oh, I cannot wait! My voice will carry us through this battle and those after it.
Just in time. The crew could use a pick-me-up.
Grr...
What is it, Marseillaise? You did great.
Exactement. I did great. My country's leaders have failed me.
You mean the broadcast? I thought it was inspiring. A little generic, maybe, but...
That's the whole point! They cut out half of it! Everything after I vowed to fight for the freedom of the people against the tyranny of the Morganas...

Fields.MenuText: It sounds like you got the important part out of the way.

Fields.DialogueText: I got an important part out of the way.
I exhorted the soldiers of France to continue on against all trouble, that this war was only the beginning.
We've much work to do once the European war is finished and the fascists swept into the dustbin of history. How many princes, warlords, and captains of industry menace the people in peacetime?
The people have the right to know what their avatar is saying.
Any second now we should be hearing your broadcast.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: What did they cut out?
That's dishonest of them.

Fields.DialogueText: It is not just the Morganas that hold people in bondage, Capitaine.
Not just dishonest. Deceitful!
The beginning?
I'm starting to see why they doctored your message.
I hear you. But there's only so much we can say in our capacity as public servants.
There will be no servants at all when my work is done!
One step at a time, Marseillaise. Come on. I'll put on some tea. Keep me company while I fill out the after action report?
C'est bon. You alone can keep me from setting fires.
You'll have to tell me when they read it.

Fields.MenuText: Governments aren't exactly in the business of revolution.
We'll get your message out, Marseillaise. Maybe not today, but we'll get it out.
They just did the other day.

Fields.DialogueText: That's why revolutions were invented!
But when!? We cannot choose the time of revolution... but we can make very spirited suggestions!
Don't make me spell it out, Capitaine. I'm not in the mood for violence.
You know that my heart beats for the people of France... but we are just one people.
You have a big heart, Marseillaise. And France needs you. But the people in charge are only human. They don't know what might happen if you get carried away.
Maybe I haven't been getting carried away enough. Merde, I let them question my foreign crew's loyalty... their very commitment to freedom! Americans, Japanese, Britons...
Doesn't that represent tragedy and upheaval?
More personal than that. When something you trust turns out to be untrustworthy... that is what the Tower means.
*ALARM*
So it's not just about Morganas attacking.
You haven't failed any of us. The fact that we're floating proves that.
I appreciate you saying so, Capitaine. I just... I just wish it were enough.
@BATTLE
The press have been raving about your message, Marseillaise.
Maybe the cards were right. I saw a Tower in that last reading I did, you know.
Non. It's about failing my loyal crew because I thought France was ready for... for...
We have come so far from the Revolution... but we need no kings or emperors to conquer and subjugate others. Even today there is poverty and prejudice in our empire.
That's what I wanted to say. That's what I pledged to destroy, once the immediate threat has passed. And they just... threw it away.
I'm not reading it.
You're a popular Belle, Marseillaise. They want to talk to you about-
More propaganda. I may love my country, Capitaine, but I will not work with anyone who denies its sins.

Fields.MenuText: We can't solve all the world's problems at once.
I understand. It's like having your hands tied.
What about the people who want to hear you?

Fields.DialogueText: But neither can we ignore them!
It's deeper than that, Capitaine. So much deeper.
Do they, Capitaine? Or do they want to hear what they think I am?
I was born with freedom written into my soul! To be silenced when I call for it is... is...
Never mind. What do they want?
They wanted to know if you'd be willing to gather the crew for a photo shoot. Just a group picture to show everyone the team out here.
And not an interview or a spoken message, naturellement.
*ALARM*
I may have a solution after all, Capitaine. Something that will satisfy both the revolutionaries out here and the old men back home.
What kind of solution?
@BATTLE
What sins?
Empire. Conquest. The whole damned "civilizing mission." If we bring anything to the world, it should be freedom, not a new set of chains!
Something to look at, rather than listen to. I know it sounds bad, but this might win you a bigger platform for when the world is ready to hear you say what you really want to.
To hear what I... hmm. But what if they did not?
Didn't what?
Not being heard is no reason for silence. It is as true today as it was when it was first written...
I was starting to miss the dust and dirt.
Enjoy it, Capitaine. Once we know when the camera crew is coming, it's all getting cleaned up again.

Fields.MenuText: You'd think the crew would get sick of deep cleaning.
Always putting your best foot forward.
You must be the cleanest ship in the Fleet.

Fields.DialogueText: Not so, Capitaine! I've scrubbed and swept with them all they way. And not to brag, Capitaine, but the cleaning crews fight over me.
Revolution is bloody, but it doesn't have to be messy.
I think the Germans and Japanese have us beat there. Fascists have style, if absolutely nothing else.
In the meantime, I'm starting my little uniform project anew.
Always a hole or a rip to patch.
Not when I'm done with them. See?
Looking sharp. Is... Marseillaise, is that a letter there on the breast?
Oh, this R right here? I suppose it is.
Marseillaise...
Whatever you think I'm up to, Capitaine, please-
Don't worry. I trust what you're doing. Just... please don't be discouraged if it doesn't work out.
Huh. This is surprisingly strong.
*ALARM*
Only to show that I cannot be moved. Not from anything I've dedicated myself to, body and soul.
@BATTLE
Hmm. Feel this thread I'm using, Capitaine. Go on, try to break it.
Plucked from my head this morning.
Wait, this is your hair?
It's resilient and I never seem to run out. Why not use it for small jobs like this?
It's convenient, I suppose. Nobody else finds it... weird?
Bien sûr que non. Whatever I can provide is not only mine. It belongs to the crew, to France... even to you.
That's... Thank you, Marseillaise. But what does this have to do with this project of yours?
And certainly not from a fight for our lives! Aux armes, citoyens!
You know, something's just occurred to me.
D'accord. We need more bouillabaisse.
No. Well, yes. I mean... How are you getting those letter patches off of the uniforms once the whole publicity stunt is over?
Seam ripper. My hair's strong, Capitaine, but it's not wire.
Got it.
Say... do you see that, Capitaine?

Fields.MenuText: That's a cute word for vandalism.
The fishing grounds?
That means danger, right?

Fields.DialogueText: Today's vandalism is tomorrow's art, Capitaine!
If only I could weave my hair into a net...
Au contraire! We may have reached the end of our quest.
Now the perfect rascasse rouge may be within our grasp. All we have to do is raise the fishermen and ask to trade for a share of their haul.
What have you got to trade today?
Hmm... this pack of playing cards with the American presidents on the sevens up... some sheet metal... and a cuckoo clock.
Merde. Speaking of... pass me that seam ripper, won't you, Capitaine?
Merci.
"Le Chariot..." Is that a fishing boat?
Hmm... Let me fetch the charts, Capitaine.
The ones that you drew on.
Je le savais! We're right in the middle of one of the red zones.
Where do you find all this stuff?
Ask the crew, Capitaine. They're the ones I trade with.
*ALARM*
Merde! Faster, Capitaine! There are innocent lives at stake!
@BATTLE
A minute later and we would have been thrown into the witches' brew. We owe you our lives!
Think nothing of it, mon ami. My first loyalty is to the people.
You're certainly dressed for it! Could have stepped straight from the pages of a history book.

Fields.MenuText: Shall we trade for some of the haul?
How do you figure these things out?
This doesn't change how I feel about the charts.

Fields.DialogueText: Think nothing of it, Capitaine. It is the least we can do.
Lots of reading, trading for information... and maybe a bit of help from the cards. Might we trouble our new friend for some fish?
Non, it does not have to. But you will feel better with some bouillabaisse in you!
We have you to thank for our successful haul. It is as much yours as ours!
*ALARM*
Think nothing of it. These waters are dangerous!
@BATTLE
It's a Belle thing. Something to do with her name and origin.
Say... what were you fishing for, anyway?
Oh, a bit of this, a bit of that. This happens to be prime ground for-
Rascasse rouge!
Oui! The lady is a connoisseur!
And an artist to boot.
You see, Capitaine? I was right!
Now then, at the risk of overstaying our welcome...
We'll be patrolling the area. Au revoir, mon ami!

Fields.MenuText: What did he mean by that?

Fields.DialogueText: Besides, we haven't a moment to lose. We're picking up the propaganda crew any day now.
Hospitality is important, Capitaine! We must feed the revolution to fight it.
And the counterrevolution.
I hope you will trust me to express myself, Capitaine.
Implicitly. I've never known you to start something you couldn't stop.
Merde. That is the whole point of a revolution.
You know what I mean. Whatever mess you make, you're dedicated to fixing. I wish more people thought the way you do.
Merci, Capitaine. I think that's why we Belles are here... to fix the world. That's why anyone is here... or at least, it should be.
*ALARM*
Or at least, to fix a very specific problem.
There's only so much the Fleet can do for you if you keep risking yourselves.
We are old, mademoiselle Marseillaise. We've braved storms that would rock a ship like you to her keel. What are Morganas but storms with pretty faces?
Here we are in port. I guess there's no convincing you to fish from the shore, is there?
Let us worry about that. We have no trouble seeing what is in front of us. You two could learn a thing or two, could you not?
Oh... I haven't the slightest idea, Capitaine. Shall we go to the galley and cook up some bouillabaisse?

Fields.MenuText: I can't decide if they're brave or insane.
We are not spending this war babysitting some fishermen.

Fields.DialogueText: This is the Republic and universal suffrage reigns. They have the right to be reckless.
We will do what we can for them, Capitaine. The war cannot forget the innocents.
Are you a light cruiser or a hotel?
Well, don't go anywhere once it's fixed. I could get used to you.
And I to you, Capitaine. Very much so.
@BATTLE
All right, what's on the itinerary for our guests' visit?
Much the same things as the last one. But bouillabaisse is included this time! Good bouillabaisse, too.

Fields.MenuText: I thought the last bouillabaisse was pretty good.

Fields.DialogueText: Once you taste this bouillabaisse, you will see there is no going back!
I just hope I can do the cause some justice.
I am defending her masters, Capitaine. West Africa... Indochina... What will we do with our ill-gotten gains when the danger has passed?
All excellent questions people will be more willing to entertain when it has passed, naturellement.
They will because you'll remind them what they rose up for a hundred and fifty years ago.
Even the Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen did not rule out slavery. And Napoleon reinstated it. We must be constantly moving forward, or be dragged back.
So how do you plan on having the photo shoot move us forward?
Those little patches on the breast?
*ALARM*
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: When is the shoot?
Don't get too revolutionary on them.

Fields.DialogueText: They have requested to do one shortly after an engagement. I suppose they think there is a certain ambience in a recently fought battle.
It is taking every fiber of my being not to get up onto a box and sermonize.
You're defending France on the front lines. What could be more just than that?
Starting a conversation, Capitaine. Getting the ball rolling. The standing arrangements have already been approved.
The camera crew were happy not to have to. The uniforms I've altered will spell out "France is not free until her colonies are free." Dead center.
Which you worked out.
If I cannot be brazen, I will be subversive!
Marseillaise, what's the matter?
That photo the crew stood for. It's in all the French papers, and the London Times... even the Americans are having a look at it.
It's a really well-composed shot. The way you hold the flag while everyone's-
Look at it, Capitaine! Look at how it's been doctored!

Fields.MenuText: I'm not seeing the difference.
You do seem a little more... endowed.
They edited out your message?

Fields.DialogueText: The letters, Capitaine! They're missing!
Now, really, Capitaine! They're reactionaries, not pigs.
They're getting quicker about it. I suppose they're watching me extra carefully since last time.
I thought for sure I'd slip one past them this time.
I just thought... hmph. Do you remember the fishing boat?
Le Chariot. What about it?
It's a tarot card as well... one I saw in the last reading I did. I thought seeing it out in the world might have been... a sign.
I think you've told me about that one. Perseverance and success, right?
Perseverance, Marseillaise. That doesn't mean you'll succeed in the near future. It just means you'll get back up when you're knocked down. I really like that about you.
@BATTLE
Grr...
You will, Marseillaise. Don't give up.
And along with the Lovers... honesty, steadfastness, and unity. That one's about resolving contradictions, you know. What greater one is there than wanting to save my country and fix it?
Ah... well, as long as we're on the subject of honesty...
*ALARM*
Morganas! Démons aux mille mensonges!
Oui, Capitaine, I understand. Nor did we have this conversation. I am in fact not talking to you right now.
Marseillaise! How's it going?
Capitaine, I was just coming to talk to you about... is that who I think it is?

Fields.MenuText: That depends on who you think it is.
Ah, you've caught me. I'm a spy for the Morganas!
No.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't play games with me! I'd recognize that weather-beaten face anywhere.
Capitaine, if you are a spy for the Morganas, I am Marie Antoinette.
You cannot lie to me, Capitaine. I see that smile on your face!
I thought we were keeping Le Chariot far away from the battlefield.
Believe it or not, I didn't invite them. We ran across them ourselves here in the red zone.
Now, you didn't get this from me.
Capitaine!
There she is. Better disappear.
Simplicity itself! I was never here.
... I mean, in this stretch of sea.
Admit it, Capitaine. You are becoming attached to my amateur cartography.
Cartography or gastronomy?
A little of both. But as we've yet to deplete the rascasse he gave us, I must wonder...
*ALARM*
... And wonder, and wonder, and wonder.
Think of it as a surprise. I believe it was you who said uncertainty furthers the human mind.
Grr... I am not human, Capitaine!
@BATTLE
More bouillabaisse, Capitaine?
I literally couldn't eat another bite. We've got enough to last us the rest of the tour.
I'll have to enlist the crew's aid. They'd leap at the chance!

Fields.MenuText: If you're up to making bouillabaisse for a few hundred.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, certainly not alone. Be careful you do not volunteer yourself! En fait, you already have.
Although this does remind me... you still have yet to tell me what Le Chariot was doing here.
It's easier to show you.
Capitaine... this photo... it's mine!
Undoctored. I wined and dined one of the camera crew for a couple.
A couple? But then the other...
Well on its way to a newspaper from an anonymous source.
Sped along by Le Chariot...
Well, they do not deal in specificity.

Fields.MenuText: Until the fish ran out.
If I never eat another bite, it'll be too soon.

Fields.DialogueText: Then we had better protect our civilian fishermen, had we not?
Too much of a good thing, eh? Respectable. The front lines are no place for complacency!
*ALARM*
Did the cards tell you that?
What about surprise?
Even for those who interpret and ponder them half to death... very pleasant ones.
@BATTLE
Interesting communiqué from La Marine Nationale.
Sternly worded?
A leak we found and plugged. Pratique.
And yet... they've also lodged a complaint with the civilian government regarding media relations.
Ha! Jealous that they don't get to censor me themselves, no doubt. They are welcome to try.

Fields.MenuText: You'll find a way around it, no matter who's doing the censoring.
They underestimate the power of fishermen.
I'm surprised they went to bat for us.

Fields.DialogueText: Progress cannot be shackled, Capitaine. Only diverted for a little while.
Censorship is a sieve, Capitaine, and the voice of the people flows like water.
There are idealists in Toulon yet.
The International Labour Organization's having a field day, in the meantime. They've been writing the Navy nonstop for an audience with you.
Well, Command's putting a lid on that for now. Something about not wanting to appear political where the land situation's concerned.
Hmph. Silence is political too.
They've had similar discussions with some of the Axis and Soviet Belles. Something about propaganda targeting working class and minority populations in Allied countries.
You do not have to be from an enemy nation to point out the sins of your own.
It's complicated. I'm not going to say fight one war at a time... but if we're fighting Morganas and inequality both, you're not doing it alone.
The feeling's mutual, Marseillaise.
*ALARM*
Hand in hand.
@BATTLE
Cautiously worded. They've made it clear that however that undoctored photo got to the London Times, we're to see that it doesn't happen again.
A Belle espousing universal liberty... what a coup!
En vérité, Capitaine... there is no one I would rather fight with than you.
From one battlefield to another?
All right, Capitaine, enough bouillabaisse.
I am learning many new things about myself. Now let's learn about the two of us.
Tarot cards?
Just to get the imagination flowing.

Fields.MenuText: I still don't know if I believe in it.
I'd be happy with the bouillabaisse.
Is what these cards say set in stone?

Fields.DialogueText: You don't have to believe in magic to appreciate the thought experiment.
I appreciate your appreciation, but you must look a little more to the future.
Only if you are a poor sculptor.
Standard three-card reading?
For our purposes, that will suffice. Past, present, future. Let's see...
Ace of cups. Chariot again. And... ten of pentacles.
Mon Dieu.
That bad?
That good. Inspiration and compassion... irrepressible courage... and a promising and prosperous future.
So... drinking with fishermen will lead to success.
It's certainly led us to where we are now. And I like where we are.
Fighting Morganas?
Never thought I'd hear you say that.
*ALARM*
That too.
@BATTLE
You know, I could get used to working down here.
The heat is not so bad when shared, no?
Hand me that seam ripper.
I like... finally having some quiet and some privacy with you, Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: We're not alone down here, you know.
We should do these projects more often.
It's nice not to have the government interfering.

Fields.DialogueText: Non, but the engines drown out our sweet nothings quite nicely.
The fight for freedom never ends. We will find more.
I do take pride in our partnership, but now and again I prefer to be a little selfish.
Should we keep these letters?
I like that idea. It's important to keep a record of these things.
... I was just suggesting another project to keep us occupied. But I am glad my revolutionary spirit has infected yours.
I wouldn't say "infected."
C'est vrai. Too negative. Hmm...
*ALARM*
Just when I thought we'd find the right word...
Who said that?
Someone who believed in building those tomorrows. Why don't we try it together?
If you like. Perhaps we can make a quilt of them.
Even if we don't start the fires of revolution blazing, someone has to keep the coals smoldering.
Maybe not today, Capitaine. But that is revolution, is it not? If you wish to understand it, call it progress. And if you wish to understand progress, call it tomorrow.
@BATTLE
... "Inspired."
Hm?
Instead of "infected." From before? "Inspired."
It's mutual, Capitaine.
